title: Dynamics of Beam Interaction and Damage within a Thin TEM Specimen
content: Specimen heating is an unavoidable consequence of the inelastic scattering of primary electrons. For a thin-slab specimen, the temperature at the center of the beam increases with a time constant that depends on the beam radius R and to a lesser extent on the distance R0 to the heat sink [1]. The temperature rise Î”T is typically below 10 K for beam currents of 1 nA or less; see Fig. 1.
